last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>86883102
If you have trouble keeping NPCs consistent you need to write yourself rules for them. The rules don't have to be complicated, but keep them in the front of your mind. The line between a hammy and exaggerated NPC and a memorable and interesting one is not impossibly thin, it does not exist.

For example, lets take your rich noble bastard. Put that on a notecard, in big all caps "RICH NOBLE BASTARD". Then write the following:
1. What he wants: keep this in the front of your mind, this gives them direction. He wants riches, or he wants to be king, or he wants the princess to himself, whatever it is it's why he matters. Caveats and exceptions can be very important here too: maybe he wants to take over a neighboring fiefdom, but it's going to be different if he wants to do so by force or lawfully.
2. What he is: What can he do? Does he have a lot of men? Is he the wealthiest of the nobility? Second richest? Is he charismatic? Both what he has and what he is good at (or bad at) will also inform his behavior.
3. What he does: Does he stutter? Does he ramble? Does he delegate responsibility? Does he tell riddles? You already know what he wants and what he can or can't do, decide now a single (or a few) ancillary characteristic, something that makes him stand out.

At its simplest, you have an NPC:
"RICH NOBLE BASTARD
-Wants to be made ruler of neighboring counties, but lawfully recognized by the king.
-Dye Trade makes him richest noble. Backroom network of spies and deals with trade guilds. Not very handsome, but exceptional negotiator and affable. Insecure.
-He thinks with his hands, always playing with a puzzle or fiddling with things even when talking to others. In spite of this, he's never distracted."

Give him stats and skills where needed and refer back to it often. What he chooses to do and how he behaves can be made easier just by having things like this to touch on.

okay this thread is filled with bad answers.
just copy characters you find interesting.
thinking about character motivations and whatnot is hard and time-consuming and you're never really sure if you're doing it correctly or the character will come out as intended so just steal shit from other places.

the problem with creating your own npc's is that your imagination will always bring you to the same main styles so npc's end up always being the same and it's hard to believe on your own judgement on wether a character you've come up on the spot will feel realistic or not. So it's much easier to ask yourself how would this character that already exists act upon a given situation.
you can use real people too and it ends up being better for the most part but generally less interesting in terms of originality

https://grognardia.blogspot.com/2022/12/sir-pellinores-advice-to-referees.html

Decent advice from 1978:
>To start the game you must at least make a town for the adventurers to start in. You can add the world outside the town, kingdoms, orc tribes, wandering monsters, elves, magic places, shrines, treasures, monsters, thieves and all kinds of other adventures for the other players to find.

>In your world don't make it impossible to survive. Since you must tell the other players what's happening and what effects their actions have you are their eyes and ears. Give them all the information you can.

>Don't be too generous or it takes the fun of the struggle out of the game.

>Don't be too stingy or no one will want to play.

>Let the players do what they want unless it is impossible. After all, it's their neck.

>Try to be realistic. Read up on the middle ages so you'll get a good idea of how things went then.

>Don't make your world too civilized. If there's no monsters around to fight the players will take to robbery to make life interesting.

>When you create your area, start by making a map of the area with graphpaper at a scale of 5–10 miles to a square. Then make maps of a larger scale of areas that should be more detailed, like castiles towns etc. Fill in all the smaller details with your imagination when a player comes to them.

>Any rules for anything that is not here feel free to make them up. But, remember, because there are no winners or losers don't feel you have to destroy the other players. Everyone can be a winner! So be just and fair!

last_replies.com:
>>86875793
there's nothing wrong with looking at historical deities and mashing them together to create your own. avoid anything too contradictory, but also remember that real religions are messy and contradictions do exist. also there'll be regional differences. a race may have a common pantheon, but certain gods will be more or less popular in different areas, beliefs about the gods will vary a bit in different areas, and there'll likely be syncretism in the areas that border other religions assuming they're not diametrically opposed
but beyond that you could create them based off things like virtues. you have a lot to choose from, but keeping it easy and going with platonic virtues you have the god you pray to to help you find the correct path with whatever issue you're facing, the god you pray to for (inner) strength, the god you pray to to help tame your vices, and the god you pray to to right wrongs. there'll be some obvious character traits for those gods, but there are of course many fables to help guide you
or without being so rigid, just think "why would anyone pray to this deity?". a mother goddess that created life and keeps it in order, worshipped by mothers to be and rulers. either a warrior god that most people worship most of the time, or split it up into a warrior god almost exclusively worshipped for strength and winning battles, and a truly everyman's god that's maybe even considered an elevated human, a semi-mythical ancestor who saved the early tribe from a catastrophic famine. and then maybe a god for the selfish desires, the sorts of things unfit to ask of the other gods. matters of love, jealousy, and petty revenge
for names think of a few one word descriptions for the god, then look them up on wiktionary in the languages best fitting your fictional culture/race. something might work with minor tweaking in russian or serbian, or you might have to go back to proto-slavic or proto-balto-slavic and maybe tweak quite a bit. requires a bit of tism

threads.com:
It's a Holy Jolly December, can we ever be redeemed? Welcome to the December thread of homebrew discussion on /tg/. This is part of my effort to get people discussing classic homebrew discussion and assist the board in general when it comes to their game design endeavors.

>Who is this namefaggot?
I'm just a dude who writes games and likes the homebrew discussions on /tg/. I frequent a few threads, but I'm just here to facilitate discussion. I was [BusinessMaxxing] in the UK last month, I'm back and scored some fackin' goals.

>Why should I homebrew?
/tg/ products are fairly unique in that it's actually pretty simple to make them these days, with a plethora of products to assist in making and playtesting your game. Making your own games helps understand why games are made the way they are, as well as being fun to do.

>What you should post
Ideas for games, games you're currently making, updates to your own games in broad strokes, and any homebrewing for existing products that don't get much attention. Discussion about the above is welcome. Post good, be good, and look over others products, they care if someone looks more than anything.

>Oh No! The Thread is Over!
Have no fear, the thread will resume at the first of every month. If you want to make another during the month, go for it. I can't, and won't, stop you. If you want to make a thread on your own game, go for it!
One suggestion: Don't add General to the name. Mid-Month Threads are "relatively" common.

I'm working on my setting's deities, how do you all feel about dual nature gods? And by that I mean good/evil people will worship the same god for different reasons. For instance Bane in Forgotten Realms is the god of war and conquest. Bane himself is Lawful evil. Succinctly, he believes the strong should rule the weak, decadent and corrupt rulers should be overthrown. Someone who is Lawful Evil would worship him because they have a desire for power and to rule, while someone who is Lawful Good would worship him because they want to bring order to a chaotic, lawless land of corruption. I was inspired by pic related, and the whole "one man's terrorist is another man's hero."

Also, second idiea. Most of the time, demons/devils are fallen angels or at least descended from them, and that's where they came from. What if it was the opposite? Angels and good gods come from demons and evil gods that redeemed themselves. Or that the good gods are positive reflections of the evil gods.

>>86898935

I find that PBTA is an incredibly powerful system if you are in a solid group that wants to collaborate on how their characters act and feel. I quite like it, but it's unfortunate the system is mostly championed by some of the least competent roleplayers or writers possible.

>>86898885

If you shrug off the blatantly obnoxious window-dressing, it's a combat focused PbtA riff meant to build an ideologically flawed character that will butt heads with the rest of the party for the sake of roleplay, and gets its power from indulging in, or transcending that ideological failure.

Examples would be a character that is slavishly devoted to their patron and refuses to consider them or their cause flawed, or a character that is tied to a number of strict traditions and falters when forced to act outside or contrary to them.

Like all PbtA, it's meant to make messy relationships, conversations and alliances even in a party that is ostensibly fighting the same enemies.

I saw this sentiment posted earlier and I feel like it deserves its own thread

>An actual rpg.net faggot finding their way here. Fascinating.
>You know that you're the reason nothing interesting gets published for the hobby anymore, right?

I see this sentiment *A LOT* on /tg/ and I don't understand it.

What do you mean "nothing interesting?" What is meant by that phrase? Is that no new games are coming out? Untrue. TTRPGs are enjoying something of a renaissance right now. The barriers of entry for publishing a role-playing game are lower now than they have ever been. Just about anyone can publish a game. Classic RPGs are getting new editions, and rules are being cloned an integrated upon. There is vitality and diversity (as in actual diversity of game options) in the market to a degree that I haven't seen since the 1990's comics boom.

Do you mean nothing "edgy" gets published anymore?
BULL
FUCKING
SHIT

Mork Borg features suicide cults, religious persecution, miscarriages falling into the gutter and being raised by rats and children executed by encasing them in porcelain dolls till they starve.

Zweihander's version of both Orcs and Beastmen are explicitly stated to rape human women. This is a restoration of the Beastmen's Broo origins and something GW would never do in a million years.

Lamentations of the Flame Princess is an edgelord's paradise.

KULT features a published scenario where you can swap bodies with a sex-trafficked 15 year old Filipino girl, leaving her mind in your gross, middle-aged ass either forever or until said body is killed by a Gang boss.

Furthermore, why are you still citing RPG.net of all things? RPG.net haven't been relevant for at least 10 years. RPG discussions moved to Social Media. Reddit and Twitter suck, but most of the productive RPG discussion takes place on Discord.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>86898601
>Given that many players already like to homebrew and come up with their own ideas

Yeah I'm not one of those people. I specifically want other people's detailed settings because I get more ideas from that than from the mechanics or a vague "I want to run something in this genre," and the restrictive nature of PbtA's narrative-focused philosophy means if I am running one of those games, I am running it with a specific goal in mind, and I find that very restrictive.

So I go back to older games that were more focused on building out whole worlds and unusual settings, because what's being published to that effect right now isn't interesting to me. Licensed IP settings and legacy settings of the hobby are what we get.

threads.com:
A cool concept which I don't see nearly as often as I think I should is biodunegons, Maps, ships and traditional dungeon crawls that are organic rather than artificial. Whether in be within a giant creature, or involving shrinking schennanigans or nightmare sequences, maps like Jabu Jabu from Legend of Zelda, ideas like the Mystery Flesh Pit national Park, and concepts like The Crimson from Terraria are all cool.

Ever run or played in a biodungeon? What was it? Have any ideas for biodungeons? Any references? Let's discuss!

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>86895351
>Ever run or played in a biodungeon? What was it?
The first game I ever ran actually, the world premise was that one day, the sun disappeared, nobody knew where, and the wizards hastily erected towers to give artificial light and warmth while the vast majority of the world slowly froze over. It really helped me keep the world physically small and still develop cultures and races.

Anyways, the sun was eaten by a Lovecraftian thing, the final dungeon of the game was about entering that thing and nuking it's heart with a magical bomb so that the sun (only marginally digested as it'd only been like 50 years or something like that) could return.
In hindsight, while a dungeon stretches credibility, a biodungeon like that is especially rough to design, because there's no conceivable logic for why there'd be traps inside or why the thing would even be navigateable in the first place.

>>86841199
From a geopolitical perspective, lasting peace between states generally comes from interdependence. A pair of states that have a lot to gain from trading with one another generally stand to profit more from peace than from war (unless one of them has a significant military advantage over the other, in which case colonialism or subjugation becomes more profitable than trade).

From that perspective, a state that relies on the undead for labor and subsistence might tend towards being more isolationist. If they have a steady supply of corpses and healthy reserve of onyx (or whatever necromancy reagent your setting uses), then they might not have much of a reason to engage in trade with other states. This is fine for the necromancer state—but it represents "lost" profits for other states. Within this dynamic, outside powers have a lot to gain from attempting to dominate the necromancy state. If the necromancers won't trade, why not make them trade (or just colonize/vassalize them outright)?

Think 19th century China and Japan. Both isolationist until forced to be otherwise.

Disclaimers:
>this is a massively simplified understanding of geopolitics, obviously
>not saying this is the only reason that the necromancy state would get invaded, this is just one take

>>86898419
The one with the higher essence cost is covered in Chummer under "used" ware. It got the nickname "omegaware" in-setting since it also encompasses inferior third-world knockoff brands and amateur cybernetics that also incur higher Essence penalties. The one that Chrome Flesh is describing and that Chummer labels as "Omegaware" is for buggy prototype ware sold on the black market as well as any other kind of ware pulled from the shelves for having some kind of unfixable serial defect. The idea is that in exchange for the product being cheaper and eating up less of your essence, you get a custom made downside worked out by your GM as compensation, like say being glitchier or having recurring maintenance issues.

First let me get this out of the way to avoid shitposting over the use of the word.
-punk:
>a world built on one particular technology that is extrapolated to a highly sophisticated level (this may even be a fantastical or anachronistic technology, akin to retrofuturism), a gritty transreal urban style, or a particular approach to social themes.

Basically, most gothic horror is typically set in real world historical analogues, with a tinge of magic here or there that adds a more fantastical element to it.

However, what I'm trying to do is craft a purely fantastical setting of this grimdark Horror-Based curses world, where several elements of the technology and societal structures are heavily based around the horror aesthetic. Things that are not even remotely possible in real life, based on the belief and understandings people had about science back on victorian times, extrapolated to such a degree to where it totally shapes the world into something totally different from ours.

GURPS is a modular, adaptable system, capable of running a wide range of characters, settings, and play styles with level of detail varying from lightweight to completely autistic.
Optional rules allow you to emulate different genres with a single system, even switching genres within a single game.

A nearly complete archive of GURPS books can be found by those who pay attention to file extensions.
Never post direct links to the archive anywhere.

If you're wondering where to start:
The Basic Set covers everything, including a lot of optional rules you probably won't use.
A genre guide can be found in the archive, under Unofficial > GURPSgen. It tells you what extra books and articles you may find useful for many common genres.
How To be a GURPS GM is a good read even for players.
GCS (gurpscharactersheet.com) is an excellent character builder software with page references to all the books and the option to export to both Foundry and Fantasy Grounds.

>TQ
Because they're adaptable. Mechs were initially sent out as universal utility vehicles with the first waves of extra-solar colonization. You could use them as forklifts, escavators, towtrucks, or asteroid wranglers. As Earth had neither the resources or even the desire to govern the diaspora the colonies tended to erupt into bushfire wars and banditry. Mechs got pushed into combat like a pickup truck in the middle-east.

The setting starts at about 80 years since the first colonies were established. Mechs still sit in the universal combat engineer nich but occasionally branch out into sapper or spec ops roles as some planets are just too hazardous to walk on even in a hardsuit. They don't go face to face with tanks and don't transport infantry but mechs tend to get outfitted for just about every other job.

Black Friday edition. Also pencils down edition.

>What is Kingdom Death: Monster?
Monster is a Survival Horror Co-Op board game for 1-4 players about hope in a truly dark place. You awaken in a plane of stone faces bathed in eternal darkness known as the Kingdom Death, a place full of freaky (and sometimes psycho-sexual) monstrosities.

Prologue Narration: [YouTube] Kingdom Death: Monster - Prologue (embed)

The Game is broken up into 3 phases:
1. During your Hunt Phase your band of survivors traverse the world of KD in pursuit of their quarry.
2. After successfully tracking your quarry you will begin the Showdown Phase, where you must fell these horrific creatures in order to acquire precious resources.
3. After the battle, your survivors wander home with loot in hand to begin the Settlement Phase. Arm yourself by developing new weapons and bizarre structures to prepare for next year's hunt.

A successful game campaign takes place over the course of 25 to 30 'lantern years' maximum, marked by completing one full phase cycle. Watch as your settlement grows and witness the survivors write their own narrative as they age. Hone your strategy and learn from your mistakes to overcome the immense odds in this cruel and twisted nightmare scape.

>tl;dr
It's basically Darkest Dungeon meets Monster Hunter meets Berserk.

>What is Genesys?
Released in November 2017, Genesys is a pen-and-paper generic/universal RPG system and toolkit by Fantasy Flight Games and EDGE Studio, using a refined version of the system presented by their Star Wars RPGs (Edge of the Empire, Age of Rebellion, Force and Destiny). Its central mechanic is the Narrative Dice System, using pools made of specialized dice to create narrative results. The intention is for the system to be a highly flexible narrative system, adaptable to most any conceivable setting and premise.

I never see it in use outside of "Indiana Jones" hack.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>86894657

Is it possible to have multiple creation events, all of which objectively happened, which then converge into a single timeline? If so, then yea, sure. Mythological beings could all wind up spilled into the same reality, or they could each occupy their own shade of reality, overlapping with mortals but not with each other.

The standard lazy way to do this is just to say that the gods were created by human belief and that their beliefs about themselves reflect human beliefs about them. So YHVH and Geb can both co-exist and both believe that they created the world but the objective truth is that they were both created by humans.

I think it's fun to have a big divine argument where many gods claim to have created the world, and all of them are basically lying, though some are lying for good reasons and some are just exaggerating a bit. They're all full of themselves, because how could they not be?

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
More fantasy games should go for a more hyperfantasy aesthetic and thematic feel, with the proper amount of exaggeration of the fantastical elements and the threats inherent to it.

I've noticed a trend of indie games being more and more "grounded" as time goes by, and there's very little in the way of proper high fantasy these days. Now there's a lot of focus put onto more mundane aspects of the world--pastoral fantasy games where labour of the land and the struggles of commoners are more in focus than hunting dragons and cleansing great world-devouring evils, for example. If it's a sci-fi game, you're a wagie under the foot of a large corporation trying to get by. If it's a post-apocalyptic game, it's strictly about the survival aspect. Any authority system is dissected and explained down to the last little detail about how it functions and how it affects the commoners.

On the other hand, more classic fantasy (JRPGs evolved directly from this and reflect it more prominently, but I digress) have fantasy injected on every level of the world, even in the same themes that these grounded games are trying to reflect. The miners are goofy dwarves and use heavy machinery to dig, they are constantly attacked by goblins that they themselves can drive away, but they need the heroes because their mining operations have awoken a machine of an earlier age that's wrecked their machines and threatens their village, and it turns out it's an old guardian protecting an ancient treasure. The farmers struggle not against their way of life, but because a dragon is stealing their cattle and burning their crops. The king is a tyrant that enforces a nation-wide blockade that would be completely impossible to pull off in real life--that's how great his royal might is.

Not everything needs to have a deep deconstruction born from realism. Where'd the fantasy go?

last_replies.com: How does Mothership compare to the Alien RPG? I've heard very good things about both and they seem somewhat similar.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>86896316
Mothership is "lighter" in that it has less rules in general. However, that lets it play a bit faster and with less reading. Mothership is /slightly/ better for campaign play, but both are not the best for that. Alien has some very specific ideas behind it, which makes things, especially creature design and building around its Stress mechanic a little more difficult if you are doing something a bit unconventional. Alien only has its official supplements, whereas there are shitloads (of varying quality) small supplements for Mothership.

They're both good and very similar to each other. Having both, I'd say I'd break out Alien for specifically high lethality Monster focused horror games, so Alien, but also things like Jurassic Park or anything else with big angry, less intelligent monster(s) hunting the party. Whereas I'd pull out Mothership for most other scifi horror.

last_replies.com:
>>86895200
>mostly any RPG that has rules you found unique and worth looking at
In a Wicked Age isn't a great game, but it's a great method of learning how to play great games, teaching you a lot about improvisation and emotional connections.
The Alien RPG is a good example of simple dice pools and has an interesting 'stress' mechanic.
Tales from the Loop has a lot of mechanics in common with Alien while being a very different game. I think it is worth playing for breaking out of the D&D paradigm of deadly violence and for contrast with Alien, demonstrating that dice mechanics aren't actually that important.
WFRP (early editions, not sure about later ones) is good for unlearning a lot of later D&D issues like expecting things to be 'balanced' and 'fair'.
I strongly recommend specifically playing CoC rather than any old BRP system. It is by far the best implementation.
GURPS will showcase how a rules-set can be customised with a few simple elements, and gives great genre advice in its supplements. Also good to see a genuine attempt at a really flexible character creation system.

last_replies.com:
>>86888959
Personally i mainly use a personal wiki.
While there are some paid options like world anvil and the like, i prefer just using an open source program called Zim.
Its fairly simple and ive seen some even call it barebones, but it does support pluggins.
Organizing ideas in nested articles really helps me get my head around whats going on. I normally have a branch for each region and then keep its background in one page, what the players have done there in another, and things they dont know about and future plans in the last one. Any characters and locations can be kept in individual nested pages to where they are, and this way you can keep the world segmented in a way that really helps to understand the way things relate.

devil’s advocate:
dungeons are a renewable resource, and you’d only get people risking their lives / paying someone to crawl a dungeon if they either suspected treasure or needed to get whatever crawled in there out
it’s like gypsies, unless you kill all of them, they just keep procreating and moving from garbage pile to garbage pile, so in a world with goblins, kobolds, mites, giant spiders and all the other shit, a dungeon probably doesn’t stay empty very long
a “valid job” also doesn’t necessarily mean working a 9-5, an architect doesn’t design a building every day, a composer doesn’t compose a number every day, an athlete doesn’t compete every day
it could be a career of rare, large payoffs with lots of training and research in between
I wouldn’t go full animu adventurers’ guild, but a club or society of adventurers like early archeologists might work
